content: British High Commissioner's official residence in Singapore **Eden Hall** is the official residence of the [British High Commissioner to the Republic of Singapore](/wiki/High_Commissioners_of_the_United_Kingdom_to_Singapore). It is located on Nassim Road, [Tanglin](/wiki/Tanglin), Singapore. It was built in 1904 for [Ezekiel Saleh Manasseh](/wiki/Ezekiel_Saleh_Manasseh), a [Baghdadi Jewish](/wiki/Baghdadi_Jewish) merchant who sold rice and opium, and originally came from [Calcutta](/wiki/Calcutta). It was designed by the architect [R. A. J. Bidwell](/wiki/R._A._J._Bidwell), who also designed the [Raffles Hotel](/wiki/Raffles_Hotel) and the [Goodwood Park Hotel](/wiki/Goodwood_Park_Hotel). The architect [Leonard Manasseh](/wiki/Leonard_Manasseh), the nephew of Ezekiel Saleh Manasseh, was born there in 1916. Ezekiel Manasseh died in the [Changi Prison](/wiki/Changi_Prison) hospital in May 1944 during the [Japanese occupation of Singapore](/wiki/Japanese_occupation_of_Singapore), and in 1957, his stepson Vivian Bath retired to Australia and sold Eden House to the British government for the nominal sum of £56,000 and stipulated that there must be a plaque at the bottom of the flagpole: "May the [Union Jack](/wiki/Union_Jack) fly here forever". After Singapore's independence, the building was made the official residence of the British High Commissioner to the Republic of Singapore. - Media related to Eden Hall at Wikimedia Commons 1°18′37″N 103°49′18″E﻿ / ﻿1.3104°N 103.8217°E﻿ / 1.3104; 103.8217
title: Eden Hall, Singapore
